message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest Hirschsprung disease, which is caused by a failure of neural crest cells to migrate caudally to intestinal wall during embryogenesis. This leads to an absence of ganglion cells in the distal bowel and results in functional obstruction. This is supported by the retained contrast seen in the sigmoid colon on the barium enema. The other options are not related to Hirschsprung disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest Hirschsprung’s disease, the failure of neural crest cells to migrate caudally to the intestinal wall during embryogenesis. This results in absence of ganglion cells in the affected segment of the colon, leading to functional obstruction and inability to pass stool. The absence of anatomic abnormality in the upper GI study and the presence of retained barium in the sigmoid colon suggest a diagnosis of Hirschsprung’s disease. Options B, C, and D are not associated with this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and examination findings suggest Hirschsprung’s disease, which is caused by the failure of neural crest cells to migrate caudally to intestinal wall during embryogenesis. This leads to absence of ganglion cells and functional obstruction of the intestine. The failure to pass meconium and the abnormal barium enema study findings support this diagnosis. Disruption of apoptosis of intestinal cells, propelling of a polyp distally by peristalsis, and decreased blood supply to developing intestine in the embryonic period are not associated with Hirschsprung’s disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation and imaging findings suggest Hirschsprung disease, which is caused by a failure of neural crest cells to migrate caudally to intestinal wall during embryogenesis. This results in absence of ganglion cells in the affected segment of the colon, leading to functional obstruction. All of the other options are not consistent with the presenting symptoms and imaging findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptom of failure to pass meconium for the first 48 hours of life suggests Hirschsprung's disease, which is caused by failure of neural crest cells to migrate caudally to intestinal wall during embryogenesis. The other options are not associated with this condition. The upper gastrointestinal study with oral contrast demonstrates normal anatomy, which further supports the diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is showing symptoms of Hirschsprung's disease, which is caused by a failure of neural crest cells to migrate caudally to the intestinal wall during embryogenesis. This leads to a lack of ganglion cells in the distal bowel, resulting in functional obstruction and the symptoms observed in the patient. Options B, C, and D are not associated with Hirschsprung's disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest Hirschsprung disease, which occurs when there is a failure of neural crest cells to migrate caudally to the intestinal wall during embryogenesis. This results in absence of ganglion cells and decreased motility in the affected segment of the colon, leading to constipation and dilation of the colon. The other options are not associated with the symptoms described.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms presented (failure to pass meconium for the first 48 hours of life, mild dehydration, active bowel sounds, and distended abdomen with no masses identified on palpation) suggest Hirschsprung's disease, which is caused by the failure of neural crest cells to migrate caudally to the intestinal wall during embryogenesis. The complete blockage of the colon causes the retention of barium contrast solution beyond 24 hours after administration. The other options do not fit the clinical presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest Hirschsprung disease, which is caused by a failure of neural crest cells to migrate caudally to the intestinal wall during embryogenesis. This leads to a lack of ganglion cells in the affected segment of the colon, resulting in functional obstruction and failure to pass meconium. The upper gastrointestinal study and lower gastrointestinal series with barium enema help to confirm the diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms presented suggest an obstruction that is preventing the patient from passing stool. The description of a dilated sigmoid colon and normal rectum suggests Hirschsprung disease, which is caused by a failure of neural crest cells to migrate caudally to the intestinal wall during embryogenesis. Option B (disruption of apoptosis of intestinal cells) is not a known cause of obstruction. Option C (propelling of a polyp distally by peristalsis) is not consistent with the imaging findings, which show a dilated colon. Option D (decreased blood supply to developing intestine in the embryonic period) is not a known cause of Hirschsprung disease.
